I don't know how a physicist would do those two problems at 1:30, but as an engineer, I wouldn't solve either of those problems the way they described.

The lever would be a sum of moments(torques) about any given point. If it's balanced, they will sum to zero. If they AREN'T balanced, I now know exactly how much twisting force is acting on that lever, and could predict any number of ways to balance it. Using potential energy in that system would be a huge headache. Gravitational potential energy would suggest (incorrectly) that all you need to balance the beam would be to have the product of the weight and heights of each object of the lever, regardless of where the fulcrum is. I don't even know how I'd make that work correctly.

The second case with the breaks would involve finding a coefficient of friction between the break pad and the tire to find the torque on the wheel, instead of trying to figure out how much the definitely not closed system is heating up. Also, both of these calculations would need to be repeated for the tire on the road, and I don't want to run the heat calculations for a tire on asphalt.

Energy CAN be a great way to simplify physics problems, but heat/friction is probably the worst place to try and apply that.
